compute.create_d3js_json(deriv_id: str, path_to_db: str) → str[source]¶

Produce a JSON file that contains something like {

“nodes”: [
{“id”: “Myriel”, “group”: 1, “img”: “/static/test.png”, “width”: 138, “height”: 39, “linear index”: 1}, {“id”: “Napoleon”, “group”: 1, “img”: “/static/test.png”, “width”: 138, “height”: 39, “linear index”: 2}

], “links”: [

{“source”: “Napoleon”, “target”: “Myriel”, “value”: 1}, {“source”: “Mlle.Baptistine”, “target”: “Myriel”, “value”: 8}

]

}

for inspiration based on the last time I implemented this, see v3_CSV/bin/create_json_per_derivation_from_connectionsDB.py

Args:

Returns:

Raises:

>>> create_d3js_json("000001", 'pdg.db')

compute.create_png_from_latex(input_latex_str: str, png_name: str) → None[source]¶

latex -halt-on-error file.tex dvipng file.dvi -T tight -o file.png

this function relies on latex being available on the command line this function relies on dvipng being available on the command line this function assumes generated PNG should be placed in /home/appuser/app/static/

Args:

Returns:
None

Raises:

>>> create_png_from_latex('a \dot b \nabla', 'a_filename')

compute.create_step_graphviz_png(deriv_id: str, step_id: str, path_to_db: str) → str[source]¶

for a clear description of the graphviz language, see https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/lang.html

Args:

Returns:

Raises:

>>> step_dict = {'inf rule':'add X to both sides',
                 'inf rule local ID':'2948592',
                 'inputs':[{'expr local ID':'9428', 'expr ID':'4928923942'}],
                 'feeds':[{'feed local ID':'319', 'feed latex':'k'],
                 'outputs':[{'expr local ID':'3921', 'expr ID':'9499959299'}]}
>>> create_step_graphviz_png("000001", "1029890", 'pdg.db')

compute.flatten_dict(d: dict, sep: str = '_') → dict[source]¶

convert the AST structure ‘AST’: {‘equals’: [ {‘nabla’: [‘2911’]},{‘function’: [‘1452’]}]}} to {‘equals_0_nabla_0’: ‘2911’, ‘equals_1_function_0’: ‘1452’}

from https://medium.com/better-programming/how-to-flatten-a-dictionary-with-nested-lists-and-dictionaries-in-python-524fd236365

Args:

Returns:

Raises:

>>> flatten_dict({},'_')
compute.flatten_list(list_of_lists: list)[source]¶

https://stackoverflow.com/a/5286571/1164295

Args:

Returns:

Raises:

>>> l = ['aab', 'aimign', ['agian', 'agag', ['gagag', 'gasg']]]
>>> list(flatten_list(l))
['aab', 'aimign', 'agian', 'agag', 'gagag', 'gasg']

compute.generate_html_for_derivation(deriv_id: str, path_to_db: str) → str[source]¶

Using pandoc for “tex to (html with mathjax)” might be better? https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37533412/md-with-latex-to-html-with-mathjax-with-pandoc https://www.homepages.ucl.ac.uk/~ucahmto/elearning/latex/2019/06/10/pandoc.html or tex4ht https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/68916/convert-latex-to-mathjax-html

This function assumes MathJax support and leverages the Jinja templates of the PDG Because the latex may contain strings with “{{” and “}}”, the html file is separate from the template

Args:

Returns:

Raises:

>>> generate_html_for_derivation("000001", 'pdg.db')

compute.generate_tex_for_derivation(deriv_id: str, user_email: str, path_to_db: str) → str[source]¶

In this iteration of the PDG (v7), I allow for inference rule names to have spaces. In previous versions, the inference rule names were camel case. When I implemented this function, I learned why the inference rule names had been camel case: Latex doesn’t like newcommand names to have underscore in them; see https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/306110/new-command-with-an-underscore Therefore, I remove all spaces from the inference rule name

Args:

Returns:

Raises:

>>> generate_tex_for_derivation("000001", 'myemail@address.com','pdg.db')

compute.modify_latex_in_expressions(global_id_of_latex_to_modify: str, revised_latex: str, user_email: str, path_to_db: str) → None[source]¶

re-use existing global ID

http://asciiflow.com/ suppose there is a step that has the following

+——————–+ +————+

+———> | old global expr ID |—>+ old latex | | +——————–+ +————+

+—–>+ expr local ID | | +—————+

step ID
+—————+
+—–>+ inf rule name |

after the change, we have

+—–>+ expr local ID | | +——-+——-+

+—+—–+ | +——————–+ +———–+ | step ID | +———–>+ new global expr ID | | new latex | +—+—–+ +——————–+ +———–+

+—————+
+—–>+ inf rule name |

Args:

Returns:
None

Raises:

>>> modify_latex_in_expressions('pdg.db')

compute.search_expression_latex(pattern: str, path_to_db: str, delimiter='\\s+') → dict[source]¶

based on search_list_of_strings adapted to dat[‘expressions’] to find latex and return a modified dat[‘expressions’]

Args:

Returns:

Raises: >>> search_expression_latex(‘pdg.db’)

compute.search_list_of_strings(pattern: str, list_of_strings_to_search: list, delimiter='\\s+') → list[source]¶

contributed by msgoff https://github.com/allofphysicsgraph/dynamic-search/blob/master/search.py

when multiple terms are present in the pattern, then search “term1 AND term2 AND term3” in the list of strings default is to split each string in the corpus on spaces

Args:

Returns:

Raises:

>>> list_of_strings_to_search = ["Normally matches any character except a newline.", "Within square brackets the dot is literal."]
>>> search_list_of_strings('(Normally|With) (anyf|char)? square', list_of_strings_to_search)
['Within square brackets the dot is literal. ']

match one of the two >>> search_list_of_strings(‘Normally|With’, list_of_strings_to_search) [‘Normally matches any character except a newline.’, ‘Within square brackets the dot is literal. ‘]

The question mark makes the preceding token in the regular expression optional. https://www.regular-expressions.info/optional.html >>> search_list_of_strings(‘(anyf|char)?’, list_of_strings_to_search) [‘Normally matches any character except a newline.’, ‘Within square brackets the dot is literal. ‘]

exact match >>> search_list_of_strings(‘square’, list_of_strings_to_search) [‘Within square brackets the dot is literal. ‘]

look for a math expression that has both “cos” and “2” present >>> list_of_strings_to_search = [‘sin(x) + cos(2x) = f(x)’, ‘ax^2 + bx + c = 0’] >>> search_list_of_strings(‘cos 2’, list_of_strings_to_search) [‘sin(x) + cos(2x) = f(x)’]

compute.send_email(list_of_addresses: list, msg_body: str, subject: str) → None[source]¶

When something goes wrong, in addition to logging the error this function could be used to send an alert to the maintainer

Args:

Returns:

Raises:
